FOREWORD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
We have officially entered the Age of Artificial Intelligence. The world is now set to change at a pace not seen in decades, even 
centuries. AI-based tools and applications make our lives easier, smoother, and richer. They help us move efficiently, get informed, 
get credit, get a job, and get our taxes done. 
 
 
But in its current form, AI reproduces and amplifies many of the social challenges we face. It is not acceptable that around a third of 
the world’s population still lacks adequate internet access. Upstream, the AI industry is highly concentrated, with just two 
countries – the United States and China – and a dozen companies accounting for a major share of the sector. This can lead only 
to greater inequality of outcomes – including gender disparities – downstream. Non-diverse AI teams, unrepresentative datasets, and 
opaque and biased algorithms can cause harm, particularly to those who are already vulnerable, whether companies or 
individuals, children and young people, women, or entire democracies. 
 
 
That is why UNESCO drafted the Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence, which was adopted in 2021 by 193 
countries to make sure AI delivers fair, sustainable, and inclusive outcomes. The Recommendation is based on the protection 
and promotion of human rights, human dignity, and environmental sustainability, and these values are then translated into 
principles such as accountability, transparency, and privacy. The Recommendation also sets out concrete policy actions that

recommendations.text: Increase the growth of digital skills, industry activity and AI development to enhance adequate economic growth. 34 CONCLUSION South Africa’s commitment to fostering an inclusive and participatory environment for the ethical and responsible development of AI is evident through the comprehensive roadmap provided by the PC4IR and related policy and legislative documents. The country’s strategic policy recommendations and supporting actions encompass crucial aspects such as regulation, creation of an enabling institutional and organisational framework, and capacity building initiatives, all directed at addressing the multifaceted challenges and opportunities presented by the burgeoning use and rapid spread of AI technology. The regulatory framework outlined emphasises the development of policies that prioritise ethical and responsible data systems and processing. Some of the existing Acts, such as POPIA and PEPUDA, uphold and emphasise rights-based protections and ethical AI practices, along with establishing cybersecurity standards and legal safeguards for high-risk AI applications. This reflects an intentional and holistic approach to governance of AI use and application. Additionally, the creation of oversight and implementation mechanisms ensures a robust regulatory environment, fostering trust and accountability in the AI ecosystem. The existence of a functional policy and institutional framework underscores the importance of an independent regulator for AI or the assignment of AI officers within existing institutions, such as the Information Regulator. This collaborative approach across regulators, institutions, and organs aims to enhance the overall effectiveness of responsible AI practices. The emphasis on capacity building, including measures to enable and safeguard AI use in the public sector, highlights a commitment to developing expertise and fostering responsible AI practices at every level. legal_regulatory.title: Legal and Regulatory
findings: LEGAL AND REGULATORY The existence of a legal and regulatory framework is the foundation for the ethical development and deployment of fair and responsible AI systems.

According to the UNESCO Recommendation, this means regulatory frameworks which place responsibility and accountability with natural or legal persons while excluding AI systems from having legal personality.
It is anticipated that creation of an AI strategy and subsequent regulations will soon be implemented in the country.

A key piece of legislation is the Protection of Personal Information Act, 2013 (POPIA) and related regulations, which govern data protection, privacy, accessibility, and processing (including automatic) of personal information.
The Act establishes the office of a data protection office (Information Regulator/”IR”) with a specific mandate.
• Requests for correction or deletion of personal data.
• The way consent is requested for processing personal data.
In addition, the Electronic Communications and Transactions Act, 2002 (ECTA) also governs the use, storage, sharing and abuse of electronic data.
strengths: The Cybercrimes Act, 2020, recently enacted, aims to establish new data-related offenses, impose sanctions, criminalize the dissemination of harmful messages, and expand the powers of law enforcement agencies in combating cybercrimes.
The bill is in response to the increasing incidents of discrimination especially on online platforms, leading to disinformation, creation of echo chambers, cyberbullying, doxing and harassment.

Existing foundational regulatory frameworks such as the Smart Africa ‘AI Blueprint for Africa’ and the African Union (AU) Data Policy framework are the only stopgaps until more comprehensive AI regulations are implemented.

Apart from the POPI Act section 71, which prohibits decisions based solely on automated decision-making systems, and PAIA provisions enabling access to information, there are no comprehensive legal obligations to disclose whether an AI system is being developed, deployed, or disseminated responsibly
gaps: The lack of national legislative regulations or government initiative to regulate AI has prompted collaboration between other sectors to move the work around managing regulation of AI and data forward.
This does not disregard existing principles, frameworks, and policies that already guide the development and use of AI/ automated decision-making systems in the country.
Although POPIA is primarily geared towards data privacy, the Act provides useful mechanisms to restrict AI systems in: • The processing of personal data.
The Act does not expressly mention ‘data,’ but given that its purpose is accountability and transparency of information, it is a useful framework in the implementation of the UNESCO Recommendation.

Apart from the POPI Act section 71, which prohibits decisions based solely on automated decision-making systems, and PAIA provisions enabling access to information, there are no comprehensive legal obligations to disclose whether an AI system is being developed, deployed, or disseminated responsibly and/or their recourse to action should it be determined otherwise.
• Signed partnerships between the National Youth Development Agency and private-sector technology companies to provide digital training for youth.
Regarding infrastructure concerns related to the digital divide, the South African government has implemented various initiatives to address ICT infrastructure backlogs and bridge the digital divide.

South Africa’s Draft National Artificial Intelligence Plan indicates strong ambitions to expand the AI market, targeting ZAR70 billion (USD3.7 billion) in government, local, and foreign direct investment in AI by 2030, with 100-300 AI startups and 5000 AI experts in the country.20 The Competition Commission South Africa (CCSA) has been playing an important role with respect to the digital economy, and how AI and algorithms are implemented by local and global firms.

The Intergovernmental Fintech Working Group (IFWG), including National Treasury amongst others, launched a regulatory sandbox during 2020 and has been testing a range of products and services with private sector financial service providers to determine the potential impact and regulatory treatment of novel technology use cases.

rankings_indices.context: Ranked 59th in the 2020 Global Cybersecurity Index, and 8th in the African region, South Africa has performed well in creating cooperative measures through bilateral agreements geared towards harmonised security measures and shared best practices.
In terms of open data, South Africa is ranked 85th out of 195 countries and a global score of 34 in the Global Data Barometer.

Ranked 86 in the Coursera Global Skills report, South Africa shows potential for growth in the areas of technology and data science, especially when coupled with the existing interests in business and entrepreneurial skills.
